protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
description: Here we describe the standardised protocol used by the Canadian Airborne Biodiversity Observatory (CABO) to measure leaf spectral reflectance and transmittance, using an integrating sphere fitted to a portable full-range field spectroradiometer. This standard version of our protocol describes the common case where an individual leaf is large enough to entirely cover the reflectance or transmission port of the integrating sphere. Briefly, six mature, healthy-looking and sunlit leaves from a canopy plant are selected for measurements of adaxial reflectance and transmittance. Leaf scans are referenced to a calibrated Spectralon® disk and corrected for stray light. Our leaf spectroscopy protocol builds from that of the Carnegie Airborne Observatory, as well as from integrating sphere user manuals from two companies (ASD Inc., SVC).
before_start:
1. Consult the user manual of the spectroradiometer and the integrating sphere to set up the instrument.
  2. The instrument should be set up in the shade, sheltered as much as possible from the elements.
  3. All canopy plants selected for measurements should have already been tagged, identified, and georeferenced before spectroscopy measurements start.
  4. The spectroscopist should be positionned as close as possible to the sampled plants to minimise time from collection to measurement.
  5. The spectroscopist should be in a confortable position and have enough room around the instrument to spread leaf samples around without the risk of mixing up individual leaves during handling.
  6. Six mature, fully-developped, healthy-looking leaves from the sunlit (>3 h per day of direct sunlight) portion of the canopy are selected for spectral measurements from the bulk leaf sample (often one of a few branches). Leaves should be collected from the uppermost surface of the branch (i.e. receiving the most direct sunlight).
warning: The lamp of the integrating sphere can get very hot and should handled from its slotted base to avoid burns.
guidelines:
Handling Spectralon®

  • Do not touch Spectralon® (e.g. sphere interior, reference disks, plugs) with your fingers.
  • Do not use canned air to remove dust on the Spectralon® disk; canned air contains chemicals that can alter Spectralon®'s optical properties.
  • Do not attempt to clean Spectralon® in the field, other than blowing surface dust only on the Spectralon® reference disk or sphere plugs using the Canless Air Duster System; cleaning Spectralon® requires a special procedure that should only done in the lab.
  • Never blow air inside of the integrating sphere, especially not when it is attached to the spectroradiometer, as this will blow dust inside the instrument.

Equipment

  • Spectra Vista Corporation HR-1024i full-range (350-2500 nm) field spectroradiometer
  • Spectra Vista Corporation 3-inch Spectralon® DC-R/T Sphere
  • Semi-rugged laptop or PDA running the SVC Scan software

  • Canless Air Duster System O2 Hurricane (never use canned air) to remove dust from the surface of the Spectralon® reference disk

  • Plastic containers with lids to temporarily store leaf samples during measurements (optional)

Consumables

  • Nitrile gloves for handling leaves
status_info: We are still developing and optimizing this protocol.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 2 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"A test can be performed to test the required startup time and system stability.  Prior to pwering on the spectrometer, setup the experiment to acquire a reference measurement (reference disk in the reference port).  Upon powering up the system , note the time, configure the instrument, and then take a SVC 'reference' measurment as quickly as possible.  Configure the  insturment to acquire 'target' measurements at an regular interval (i.e. 1 minute) over an extended period of time (i.e. 2 hours).  This will allow not only the warm-up period to be determined, but the determination of the baseline noise level."
source_data.thread_text:

source_data.annotation: Use a thin piece of paper at the exit of the reflectance sample port (empty port) the to ensure the light beam under-fills and is centered in the reflectance port. If it is not, then proceed to lamp alignment as described in the SVC integrating sphere user manual, p. 23-24.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 9 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation: Position the leaf so that the amount of leaf and vein material over the port is roughly proportional to the area of leaf and vein found throughout the leaf, while avoiding the large midrib vein. Position the leaf so that it is approximately halfway between the mid-rib vein and the leaf margin, and halfway between the tip and the base of the leaf lamina.
source_data.thread_text: Position the leaf so that the amount of leaf and vein material over the port is roughly proportional to the area of leaf and vein found throughout the leaf, while avoiding the large midrib vein. Position the leaf so that it is approximately halfway between the mid-rib vein and the leaf margin, and halfway between the tip and the base of the leaf lamina.

Position the leaf so that it is approximately halfway between the mid-rib vein and the leaf margin, and halfway between the tip and the base of the leaf lamina.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 10 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"If the multiple leaves tested in this sequence have similar reflectance/transmittance, then acquiring a single reference radiance measurment should be adequate.  However, the sensitivity of the Reference radiance in reflectance mode to the leaf reflectance levels can be tested with relative ease."
source_data.thread_text:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"If the multiple leaves tested in this sequence have similar reflectance/transmittance, then acquiring a single reference radiance measurment should be adequate.  However, the sensitivity of the Reference radiance in reflectance mode to the leaf reflectance levels can be tested with relative ease."
source_data.body:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"If the multiple leaves tested in this sequence have similar reflectance/transmittance, then acquiring a single reference radiance measurment should be adequate.  However, the sensitivity of the Reference radiance in reflectance mode to the leaf reflectance levels can be tested with relative ease."

comments.name: Etienne Laliberté
comments.comment_text: Good point. We will test it. The ASD sphere manual says it makes little difference if the leaf used is within 20% of the reflectance of the actual leaf measured, which is why I thought one reference radiance should be adquate. But worth checking.
comments.body: Good point. We will test it. The ASD sphere manual says it makes little difference if the leaf used is within 20% of the reflectance of the actual leaf measured, which is why I thought one reference radiance should be adquate. But worth checking.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 14 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation: Position the leaf to target the same area measured for the reference radiance. Position it so that the amount of leaf and vein material over the port is roughly proportional to the area of leaf and vein found throughout the leaf, while avoiding the large midrib vein. Position the leaf so that it is approximately halfway between the mid-rib vein and the leaf margin, and halfway between the tip and the base of the leaf lamina.
source_data.thread_text: Position the leaf to target the same area measured for the reference radiance. source_data.annotation: Position the leaf to target the same area measured for the reference radiance. Position it so that the amount of leaf and vein material over the port is roughly proportional to the area of leaf and vein found throughout the leaf, while avoiding the large midrib vein. Position the leaf so that it is approximately halfway between the mid-rib vein and the leaf margin, and halfway between the tip and the base of the leaf lamina.

source_data.annotation: We should add a second reference measurement in reflectance mode after all leaves are measured (see step 10) before moving into transmission mode, at least until we're confident in the stability of our system.

components.data: Remove the tethered calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard from the sphere transmission port.
components.name: Description

components.data: Remove the light trap from the transmission port sample holder.

components.data: Position the lamp over the sphere transmission port.

source_data.annotation: Make sure lamp is secured in locked position.
source_data.thread_text: Make sure lamp is secured in locked position.
source_data.body: Make sure lamp is secured in locked position.
The lamp can get very hot. Grab it by the slotted heat shield.

components.data: Install the Spectralon® plug over the primary light port.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 39 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"When the leaf is placed in the transmissin port for the Transmission mode measurments, it is likely that it will be subject ot heat form the lamp.  This heat can lead to changes at the cellular level that could impact the measured transmission.  The time that the leaf is positioned in this configuration should be minimized.  Measuring the temperature at this port and designing a destructive test to evaluate the impact of the lamp heat on the leaf is recommended."
source_data.thread_text:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"When the leaf is placed in the transmissin port for the Transmission mode measurments, it is likely that it will be subject ot heat form the lamp.  This heat can lead to changes at the cellular level that could impact the measured transmission.  The time that the leaf is positioned in this configuration should be minimized.  Measuring the temperature at this port and designing a destructive test to evaluate the impact of the lamp heat on the leaf is recommended."
source_data.body:
From Raymond Soffer 30/04/2018:

 

"When the leaf is placed in the transmissin port for the Transmission mode measurments, it is likely that it will be subject ot heat form the lamp.  This heat can lead to changes at the cellular level that could impact the measured transmission.  The time that the leaf is positioned in this configuration should be minimized.  Measuring the temperature at this port and designing a destructive test to evaluate the impact of the lamp heat on the leaf is recommended."

comments.name: Etienne Laliberté
comments.comment_text: Good point. We will minimise the measurement time by using using  the shortest scan time that leads to acceptable SNR in the SWIR2.
comments.body: Good point. We will minimise the measurement time by using using  the shortest scan time that leads to acceptable SNR in the SWIR2.

components.data:
The equation for adaxial reflectance of leaf i, ρleaf,i is

 

ρleaf,i = (Rtar,i − Rstr) ÷ (Rref − Rstr) × ρref

 

where

 

ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
The equation for adaxial reflectance of leaf i, ρleaf,i is

 

ρleaf,i = (Rtar,i − Rstr) ÷ (Rref − Rstr) × ρref

 

where

 

ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.

components.data:
The equation for adaxial transmittance of leaf i, τleaf,i is

 

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i ÷ Tref) × ρc

 

where

 

ρc is the absolute reflectance of the cavity wall, i.e. the region of the sphere that the light beam directly hits in configuration D (i.e. transmission mode, reference).

 

Because the SVC sphere interior is made of Spectralon®, if ρc is unknown, it can be reasonably approximated by ρref, leading to

 

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i ÷ Tref) × ρref

 

where

 

ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.
components.name: Description

where

 

ρc is the absolute reflectance of the cavity wall, i.e. the region of the sphere that the light beam directly hits in configuration D (i.e. transmission mode, reference).

 

Because the SVC sphere interior is made of Spectralon®, if ρc is unknown, it can be reasonably approximated by ρref, leading to

 

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i ÷ Tref) × ρref

 

where

 

ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 33 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation: This corresponds to the reference radiance in transmission mode (Tref).
source_data.thread_text: This corresponds to the reference radiance in transmission mode (Tref).
source_data.body: This corresponds to the reference radiance in transmission mode (Tref).

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 33 of Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.protocol_name_html: Measuring spectral reflectance and transmittance (350-2500 nm) of large leaves using an integrating sphere
source_data.annotation:
Question for Raymond Soffer:
For transmittance, in the SVC manual it is suggested (p. 19) to use (see also step 52 below)

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref) * ρref

where

τleaf,i is the transmittance of leaf i (adaxial or upper side of leaf),
Ttar,i  is the target radiance of leaf i in transmission mode (in appendix A of SVC manual, top right corner),
Tref  is the reference radiance in transmission mode (this step #33 diagram; also SVC manual appendix A, top left corner)
ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.

However, as mentionned in the SVC manual, this assumes that the reflectance of the sphere cavity wall (actually what is being measured by Tref) is the same as the calibrated Spectralon standard. This is probably a reasonable assumption since the sphere wall is also made of Spectralon, but does not give a NIST-traceable measurement since it cannot be traced back to an actual calibrated standard.

Technically shouldn't we have:

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref) * ρcav

where

ρcav is the absolute reflectance of the sphere cavity wall that the light beam directly hits in Tref mode?

But this would require ρcav to be estimated...

Alternatively, could/should we use the same approach than the Li-Cor 1800 sphere (in which the reference and transmittance modes use two different lamp positions, see Fig. 2a and 2c from Noda et al. 2013 Plant Cell Env), and use (eqn. 5 of Noda et al. 2013):

τleaf,i = [ Ttar,i / (Rref  - Rstr ) ] * ρref

where

Rref is the reference radiance of the leaf abaxial (lower) side in reflectance mode (SVC manual Appendix A, bottom left corner)
Rstr is the stray light radiance in reflectance mode.

For transmittance, in the SVC manual it is suggested (p. 19) to use (see also step 52 below)

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref) * ρref

where

τleaf,i is the transmittance of leaf i (adaxial or upper side of leaf),
Ttar,i  is the target radiance of leaf i in transmission mode (in appendix A of SVC manual, top right corner),
Tref  is the reference radiance in transmission mode (this step #33 diagram; also SVC manual appendix A, top left corner)
ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.

However, as mentionned in the SVC manual, this assumes that the reflectance of the sphere cavity wall (actually what is being measured by Tref) is the same as the calibrated Spectralon standard. This is probably a reasonable assumption since the sphere wall is also made of Spectralon, but does not give a NIST-traceable measurement since it cannot be traced back to an actual calibrated standard.

Technically shouldn't we have:

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref) * ρcav

τleaf,i = [ Ttar,i / (Rref  - Rstr ) ] * ρref

where

Rref is the reference radiance of the leaf abaxial (lower) side in reflectance mode (SVC manual Appendix A, bottom left corner)

source_data.body:
Question for Raymond Soffer:
For transmittance, in the SVC manual it is suggested (p. 19) to use (see also step 52 below)

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref) * ρref

where

τleaf,i is the transmittance of leaf i (adaxial or upper side of leaf),
Ttar,i  is the target radiance of leaf i in transmission mode (in appendix A of SVC manual, top right corner),
Tref  is the reference radiance in transmission mode (this step #33 diagram; also SVC manual appendix A, top left corner)
ρref is the absolute reflectance of the calibrated Spectralon® reflectance standard.

However, as mentionned in the SVC manual, this assumes that the reflectance of the sphere cavity wall (actually what is being measured by Tref) is the same as the calibrated Spectralon standard. This is probably a reasonable assumption since the sphere wall is also made of Spectralon, but does not give a NIST-traceable measurement since it cannot be traced back to an actual calibrated standard.

Technically shouldn't we have:

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref) * ρcav

where

ρcav is the absolute reflectance of the sphere cavity wall that the light beam directly hits in Tref mode?

But this would require ρcav to be estimated...

Alternatively, could/should we use the same approach than the Li-Cor 1800 sphere (in which the reference and transmittance modes use two different lamp positions, see Fig. 2a and 2c from Noda et al. 2013 Plant Cell Env), and use (eqn. 5 of Noda et al. 2013):

τleaf,i = [ Ttar,i / (Rref  - Rstr ) ] * ρref

where

Rref is the reference radiance of the leaf abaxial (lower) side in reflectance mode (SVC manual Appendix A, bottom left corner)
Rstr is the stray light radiance in reflectance mode.

comments.name: Raymond Soffer
comments.comment_text:
I believe there is an even more fundamental error in the transmittance equation. For the setup that the LabSphere IS uses the equation should not have the reflectance term.  It should simple be:

 

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref)

 

If the leaf measurement is, for example, 50% of the reference measurement (which is a 100% transmittance measurement), then the transmittance will be 50%, independent of the reflectance of the integrating sphere (other than noise levels). The fact that the reflectance is close to 100% means this may not be immediately evident to anyone looking at the results.  I believe the reflectance term is a holdover from the Licor IS equations (and perhaps the ASD IS) in which the reference measurement was not acquired in the same geometry as the transmittance sample measurements so it came into play.  I have asked Tom Corl if I am missing anything in my assessment. He told me that the equation in their manual came from Labsphere's literature.  They are looking into it and will be checking with Labsphere.

 

I suggest we should wait until my concern is resolved and have another look at your concerns to see if they are still relavent.  Keep in mind that the Labsphere IS geometry for transmission measurments is much more straightforward than the other spheres and, I believe, less succeptably to errors. As far as NIST traceability is concerned, the transmittance equation does not have a dirrect link to it (the reflectance methodology does).  What is relevant to both methodologies is the uncertainty and how it is determined.  The uncertainty in these measurments will be impact by the the system stability and its linearity, both things that we can determine.  NIST has documention on how to do this properly.  NPL also has some very good on line tutorials.
comments.body:
I believe there is an even more fundamental error in the transmittance equation. For the setup that the LabSphere IS uses the equation should not have the reflectance term.  It should simple be:

 

τleaf,i = (Ttar,i / Tref)

 

If the leaf measurement is, for example, 50% of the reference measurement (which is a 100% transmittance measurement), then the transmittance will be 50%, independent of the reflectance of the integrating sphere (other than noise levels). The fact that the reflectance is close to 100% means this may not be immediately evident to anyone looking at the results.  I believe the reflectance term is a holdover from the Licor IS equations (and perhaps the ASD IS) in which the reference measurement was not acquired in the same geometry as the transmittance sample measurements so it came into play.  I have asked Tom Corl if I am missing anything in my assessment. He told me that the equation in their manual came from Labsphere's literature.  They are looking into it and will be checking with Labsphere.

 

I suggest we should wait until my concern is resolved and have another look at your concerns to see if they are still relavent.  Keep in mind that the Labsphere IS geometry for transmission measurments is much more straightforward than the other spheres and, I believe, less succeptably to errors. As far as NIST traceability is concerned, the transmittance equation does not have a dirrect link to it (the reflectance methodology does).  What is relevant to both methodologies is the uncertainty and how it is determined.  The uncertainty in these measurments will be impact by the the system stability and its linearity, both things that we can determine.  NIST has documention on how to do this properly.  NPL also has some very good on line tutorials.
